A Guide Through Horror Cinema's Underrated Classics

31/10/2021

Joseph William Draisey takes us through a crash course history of horror cinema

Image by Columbia Pictures

By Kyle Boulton

â€œHorror films donâ€™t create fear, they release itâ€ â€“ Wes Craven, New Nightmare (1994)

Exorcising fear since The House of the Devil (1896), horror cinema has split into an impressive array of subgenres, each targeting their own pressure point. By no means a comprehensive list, what follows is an attempt to play the Crypt-Keeper â€“ shedding light on underappreciated tales of terror hidden within prevalent subgenres.

Anthology

Popularised by the portmanteau classic Dead of Night (1945) and propelled to commercial success by the likes of Amicus and Hammer, the anthology format offers a refreshingly malleable mode of nightmare artistry. Despite running the risk of becoming an excusable dumping ground for underdeveloped ideas, this format is known for its ensemble casts and often shared directorial efforts. Attracting the collaboration between horror royalty, George A. Romero and Stephen King, Creepshow (1982), anthologies are a celebratory reminder of horrorâ€™s communal spirit.

In Rusty Cundieffâ€™s Tales from the Hood (1995), Clarence Willaims III gives an iconic performance as the charmingly nefarious funeral director, Mr Simms. The same character holds together four agitprop outings with a distinctly African-American focus. Restrained to a tight runtime and packaged in the signature pulp of EC Comics, Cundieffâ€™s anthology is sobering without being sanctimonious, making it the magnum opus of horrorcore cinema.

Adapted from their hit stage play of the same name, Jeremy Dyson and Andy Nymanâ€™s Ghost Stories (2017) harks back to the quintessential late-night thrills of Amicus, Hammer, and Tigon; achieving a respectful pastiche whilst leaving you vulnerable to the lavishly provocative tricks it keeps up its sleeve. Creatively, the duo complement each otherâ€™s talents tremendously; Dyson, being a member of the League of Gentlemen troupe, offers a dark surrealism as Nyman brings research to the table, having worked as Derren Brownâ€™s right-hand man. All of which culminates in a film which excels at condensing well-founded psychology into what is labelled â€˜existential terrorâ€™. An underappreciated masterstroke of British horror

Body

Flourishing during the heyday of practical effects, as demonstrated by the films of David Cronenberg â€“ Videodrome (1983), The Fly (1986) â€“ alongside close associate Clive Barker â€“ Hellraiser (1987), Nightbreed (1990) â€“ the body horror subgenre boasts a unique viscera that teases out anxieties surrounding social image and challenges our preconceptions of monstrosity.

In the shadow of his contemporaries, namely Cronenberg and Barker, Stuart Gordonâ€™s filmography often goes overlooked. His recognition is eclipsed even further by the towering legacy of H.P. Lovecraft, whose back catalogue provided Gordon a bounty of source material. His directorial debut, Reanimator (1985), showcases the exploits of an eccentric mortuary scientist whilst walking a fine line between schlock and sophistication, as embodied by its sharp-witted tagline: â€œHerbert West has a good head on his shouldersâ€¦ and another one on his deskâ€. Devoid of Frankensteinâ€™s philosophical sensibilities, Gordonâ€™s Reanimator is a gore-laden, neon injected, technical marvel which strives to be nothing but a good time.

With all of that said, it would be a disservice to enter the world of body horror without tipping the hat to Cronenberg. Released just months before Ivan Reitmanâ€™s â€˜rip-roaringâ€™ comedy Twins, Cronenbergâ€™s Dead Ringers (1988) presents the gloomy hellscape of co-dependency lurking on the other side of the coin. A victim of its own reservation, the unsung glory of Dead Ringers is in Cronenbergâ€™s departure from physical trauma; favouring and exploiting bodily dissociation and the haze of paranoia it feeds on, Dead Ringers produces far more haunting results.

Comedy

A litmus test for a filmmakerâ€™s discipline, the balancing act of the comedy-horror hybrid is attempted by many but mastered by few. Finding a perfect equilibrium, John Landisâ€™ An American Werewolf in London (1981) is unrivalled in this particular subgenre; a film which will have you cowering behind your pillow whilst howling â€“ nudge, nudge (wink, wink) â€“ with laughter. Nevertheless, low-budget creativity in the struggling industry of late has endured, offering up a smattering of offbeat honourable mentions.

After striking a chord with sleeper hit Thunder Road (2018), the champion of independent film, Jim Cummings, returned with the equally brilliant The Wolf of Snow Hollow (2020). The film is a brave venture into the realm of comedy-horror, armed with a razor-sharp script that has more bite than bark. Satirical takedowns of the fragile male ego are delicately mixed with a brooding terror pulled straight from the playbook of David Fincher, providing procedural scares akin to Se7en (1995) and Zodiac (2007) with a refreshing supernatural twist â€“ beware the moon.

Creature Feature

Fronted by Universalâ€™s monster mash creations and lionised as a cultural institution by late-night picture shows, the creature feature is a joyfully versatile subgenre that is still discovering new ways to shock.

Though it has been known to haunt the late night spot on Film4, AndrÃ© Ã˜vredalâ€™s magnificent found-footage flick Troll Hunter (2010) deserves to be tracked down for an uninterrupted viewing. Helmed by the Nordic equivalent of Captain Quint, on the lookout for a different set of jaws, Troll Hunter is an affectionate retelling of Norwayâ€™s rich folklore blended with a strain of socio-economic satire. In any case, if you remain on the fence about which Norwegian found-footage, troll-hunting horror romp to watch this season, make it this one.

â€œI know writers who use subtext and theyâ€™re all cowardsâ€ declared Matthew Holnessâ€™ parodic alter-ego, Garth Marenghi, as he introduced his cult classic, DarkplaceÂ (2004). But in 2018, Holness debuted the expressionistic nightmare,Â Possum, a sensitive portrait of repressed trauma. Borrowing from Basket Case (1982), a fine companion for a double bill, the protagonist physically carries his troubles around in a duffel bag containing the titular â€˜Possumâ€™, a horrific puppet from the depths of the uncanny valley, which soon enough disobeys its master.

Gothic

Bela Lugosi may be dead, with bats having left the bell tower and victims bled, but the spirit of the gothic chiller certainly lives on.

Perhaps the most overlooked entry of its decade, the neo-gothic delight of Fright Night (1985) renders the suburban mundane phantasmagorically as teenage horror fiend, Charley Brewster, suspects his neighbour to be a vampire. The stakes are raised when Charley enlists the help of horror show host, Peter Vincent â€“ an affectionate tribute to both Peter Cushing and Vincent Price â€“ in a powerhouse performance from Roddy McDowall. With a charming John Hughes character dynamic and startling creature effects rivalling that of Rick Baker, Fright Night is a should-be staple of spooky season.

Horrorâ€™s best kept secret â€“ The Exorcist III (1990) is also a phenomenal piece of gothic cinema. In the aftermath of 1977â€™s sacrilegious sequel, The Heretic, novelist turned director William Peter Blatty reclaimed the reins over his legendary source material. Anchored around a moonlit asylum, The Exorcist III is a claustrophobic ordeal that becomes cosmically terrifying once supernatural forces begin to call the shots. The film retains the thundering speeches and theatricality of its predecessor but introduces a fresh cast, an enthralling murder mystery turned ghost story, and a contender for the greatest jumpscare put to film. Altogether, The Exorcist III is a truly compelling watch.

Splatter

Thanks to the recent antics of Eli Roth and Rob Zombie, splatter has been demoted to a second-rate subgenre. Though its restoration seems imminent with the likes of Ready or Not (2019) leading the charge, in the meantime there is always the forgotten classics.

Before becoming a servant of Tolkien, Peter Jackson was the Jackson Pollock of blood, creating The Godfather for gorehounds â€“ Braindead (1992). Controlled chaos at its finest, the film is distinctive not only for its brain-melting finale but for the understated coming-of-age tale which follows the unassuming Lionel transform from errand boy to lawnmower-wielding slayer of the undead. Braindead may have a heart of darkness, but the heart is there, nevertheless.

Beautiful nightmares, and a Happy Halloween to all.
